title: Toward an ethics of autoppoietic technology: Stress, care, and intelligence
abstract: The relationship between humans and technology has attracted increasing attention with the advent of ever more sophisticated artificial intelligence. This has led to calls for an "ethics of technology" to ensure that technology serves human needs and not rather in a perverse or neglectful relationship with humans. Our model of loops of stress, care, and intelligence in this paper suggests that technology should not be seen as a mere tool or instrument, but rather as a form of artificial agency. We argue that both human and artificial agents, as well as their substrates, are intelligent and can be understood as needing to respond to a perceived mismatch between current and desired future states.
